                <div class="site-header__secondary-menu">

</ul>
</li>
<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-10311"role="menuitem"aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false" data-depth="0"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/partnerships/shield-partner-program/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Partners</span></span></span></a>
<ul role="menu" data-depth="0" class="sub-menu">
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2921"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/partnerships/shield-partner-program/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Shield Partner Program</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2922"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/partnerships/technology-partners/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Technology Partners</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2920"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/partnerships/become-a-partner/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Become a Partner</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-2923"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="10311"><a target="_blank" href="https://partners.binarydefense.com/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Partner Portal Login</span></span></span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-2914"role="menuitem"aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false" data-depth="0"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Company</span></span></span></a>
<ul role="menu" data-depth="0" class="sub-menu">
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10079769"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">About Us</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10079773"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/press-releases/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Press Releases</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5252"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/in-the-news/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">In the News</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10080606"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/browns/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Cleveland Browns</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10081504"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/michael-kim/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Michael Kim</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-10079774"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/events/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Events</span></span></span></a></li>
	<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2915"role="menuitem"data-depth="1" data-parent="2914"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/about-us/careers/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Careers</span><span class="menu-item__badge" data-color="bright-blue">We're Hiring</span></span></span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current_page_parent menu-item-10079770"role="menuitem"data-depth="0"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/" class="menu-item__link"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text">Blog</span></span></span></a></li>
</ul>                        </nav>
                    </div>
                                    </div>
        <div class="off-canvas__bottom">
                                                <nav class="off-canvas-secondary-menu shared-walker-menu" aria-label="Off-Canvas Secondary Menu">
                        <ul id="off-canvas-secondary-menu" class="menu" role="menu"><li class="will-show-mobile-menu-text-on-mobile menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-2929"role="menuitem"><a href="JavaScript:void(0)" class="menu-item__link j-toggle-search"><span class="menu-item__label"><span class="menu-item__icon material-symbols-outlined" >search</span><span class="menu-item__content"><span class="menu-item__text screen-reader-text">Search</span></span></span></a></li>
<li class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-2930 has-button"role="menuitem"><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/contact-us/" class="menu-item__link menu-item__button button">Contact Us</a></li>
</ul>                    </nav>
                                
    <nav class="social-media-menu" aria-label="Social Media Menu">
        <ul class="menu" role="menu">

    <div id="popup-overlay"></div>
</header> <!-- @end #masthead -->


                <div id="primary" class="wrap">
                    <main id="main" class="site-main">

    <header  class="entry-header">
        <div class="entry-header__wrap">
            <div class="entry-header__content">
                                <h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Wineloader &#8211; Analysis of the Infection Chain</h1>                                                <div class="post_date">Last Modified: Tuesday October 15, 2024</div>                                <p class="byline">By </p>                
            <nav class="social-share-menu" aria-label="Social Share Menu" data-style="default">
        <ul class="menu" role="menu">
                            <li class="share-url-linkedin" role="menuitem">
                    <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/wineloader-analysis-of-the-infection-chain/" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="Share this" aria-label="Share this">
                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Share this</span>
                        <i class="fa-brands fa-linkedin-in" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                    </a>
                </li>
                            <li class="share-url-facebook" role="menuitem">
                    <a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/wineloader-analysis-of-the-infection-chain/" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="Share this" aria-label="Share this">
                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Share this</span>
                        <i class="fa-brands fa-facebook" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                    </a>
                </li>
                            <li class="share-url-twitter" role="menuitem">
                    <a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/wineloader-analysis-of-the-infection-chain/&text=Wineloader+%26%238211%3B+Analysis+of+the+Infection+Chain" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="Tweet this" aria-label="Tweet this">
                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Tweet this</span>
                        <i class="fa-brands fa-twitter" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                    </a>
                </li>
                            <li class="share-url-pinterest" role="menuitem">
                    <a href="https://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/wineloader-analysis-of-the-infection-chain/&description=Wineloader+%26%238211%3B+Analysis+of+the+Infection+Chain" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank" title="Pin this" aria-label="Pin this">
                        <span class="screen-reader-text">Pin this</span>
                        <i class="fa-brands fa-pinterest-p" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"></i>
                    </a>
                </li>
                    </ul>
    </nav>
                                            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="entry-breadcrumbs"><p id="breadcrumbs"><span><span><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/">Home</a></span> » <span><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources">Resources</a></span> » <span><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/">Blog</a></span> » <span class="breadcrumb_last" aria-current="page"><strong>Wineloader &#8211; Analysis of the Infection Chain</strong></span></span></p></div>        <div class="entry-header__overlay has-320deg-bright-blue-to-dark-gray-grid-background-pattern"></div>
    </header>

<div class="post-row">
    <div class="post-col">
        
<article class="post-10080306 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-blog category-threat-research tag-arc-labs tag-managed-detection-and-response tag-mdr tag-threat-hunting tag-threat-intelligence" id="post-10080306">
    <div class="entry-content">
        
<p><strong>By <a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/arclabs/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">ARC Labs</a> contributor, Shannon Mong</strong></p>



<p>ARC Labs recently analyzed a sample of the Wineloader backdoor for infection chain analysis and detection opportunities to help defenders protect their organizations. Through this analysis, ARC Labs is providing defenders with general detection guidance and specific KQL queries to detect Wineloader activity within Microsoft Sentinel. Additionally, ARC Labs has provided some best practices when analyzing obfuscated JavaScript code within HTA files. </p>



<p>Wineloader is a modular backdoor that was <a href="https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/european-diplomats-targeted-spikedwine-wineloader">initially discovered</a><a href="https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/european-diplomats-targeted-spikedwine-wineloader" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"> by ZScaler</a> and later <a href="https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/apt29-wineloader-german-political-parties" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">reported by Mandiant</a>. It has been used in spearphishing campaigns linked to <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">APT29</a> (also known as NOBELIUM and COZY BEAR). This backdoor allows additional tools or modules to be downloaded to an infected host through an encrypted command and control (C2) channel. Wineloader is believed to be a variant of other tools associated with APT29, such as BurntBatter, BeatDrop, and MuskyBeat. </p>



<div class="wp-block-group"><div class="wp-block-group__inner-container is-layout-constrained wp-block-group-is-layout-constrained">
<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Key Takeaways from our Wineloader Analysis: </h2>



<ol class="wp-block-list" start="1">
<li>WINELOADER Overview: 
<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>WINELOADER is a modular backdoor used in spearphishing campaigns attributed to APT29 (NOBELIUM, COZY BEAR). </li>



<li>It allows additional tools or modules to be downloaded through an encrypted command and control (C2) channel. </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>



<ol class="wp-block-list" start="2">
<li>Phishing Lure: 
<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>The campaign starts with a phishing email inviting targets to a wine tasting event hosted by the Ambassador of India. </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>



<ol class="wp-block-list" start="3">
<li>Infection Chain: 
<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>The malicious website downloads a ZIP file containing an obfuscated HTA file with JavaScript code. </li>



<li>Executing the HTA file downloads another ZIP file with the Wineloader payload. </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>



<ol class="wp-block-list" start="4">
<li>Obfuscation Techniques: 
<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>The HTA file uses heavily obfuscated JavaScript, including variable renaming and string encoding. </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>



<ol class="wp-block-list" start="5">
<li>Execution and Evasion: 
<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Wineloader is executed through a malicious DLL which is sideloaded via sqlwiter.exe </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>



<ol class="wp-block-list" start="6">
<li>Persistence Mechanisms: 
<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Wineloader achieves persistence via scheduled tasks or modifying registry keys. </li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
</div></div>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">The Phishing Lure</h2>



<p>The initial infection chain of Wineloader starts with a phishing email leveraging an invite to a wine tasting event hosted by the Ambassador of India. The PDF redirects the target to a malicious website where the Wineloader infection begins. </p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" width="682" height="550" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader1.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080307" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader1.png 682w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader1-300x242.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 682px) 100vw, 682px" /></figure></div>


<h2 class="wp-block-heading">The Infection Chain</h2>



<p>The infection chain starts when the target is redirected to a malicious site that downloads a ZIP file containing a malicious HTA file with heavily obfuscated JavaScript code. When the HTA file is executed by the user, the JavaScript code executes, which downloads an additional ZIP file containing the Wineloader payload.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full is-resized"><img decoding="async" width="367" height="332" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader2.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080308" style="width:566px;height:auto" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader2.png 367w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader2-300x271.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 367px) 100vw, 367px" /></figure></div>


<h2 class="wp-block-heading">HTA Analysis</h2>



<p>ARC Labs analyzed the obfuscated JavaScript to arm defenders with strategies to extract tactical threat intelligence from obfuscated JavaScript payloads. Upon first analysis, the JavaScript within the HTA appears to be obfuscated using an open-source Java obfuscator tool that leverages variable renaming and string encoding to hinder human analysis.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img decoding="async" width="936" height="414" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader3.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080309" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader3.png 936w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader3-300x133.png 300w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader3-768x340.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 936px) 100vw, 936px" /></figure></div>


<p>ARC Labs has observed that JavaScript payloads modified using common obfuscation tools (like the one used for Wineloader) often rely on a replace function that replaces encoded values with their original string value upon execution.</p>



<p>For example, a function named replace could contain an array of hexadecimal encoded strings such as <strong>\x6e\x65\x77</strong> (new), <strong>\x41\x63\x74\x69\x76\x65\x58\x4f\x62\x6a\x65\x63\x74</strong> (ActiveXObject), and <strong>\x28\x27\x57\x73\x63\x72\x69\x70\x74\x2e\x53\x68\x65\x6c\x6c\x27\x29</strong> (Wscript.Shell).</p>



<p>To obfuscate the call for <strong>new ActiveXObject(&#8216;Wscript.Shell&#8217;)</strong>, the payload will reference the replace function, calling the appropriate element within the array.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="936" height="338" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader4.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080310" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader4.png 936w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader4-300x108.png 300w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader4-768x277.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 936px) 100vw, 936px" /></figure></div>


<p>Defenders can often extract valuable threat intelligence from obfuscated JavaScript payloads by looking for arrays of obfuscated data stored within a function that is repeatedly called when setting variable values within the payload. Simply reuse the referenced functions with <strong>console.log</strong> and pass the same data to the functions used within the payload.</p>



<p>This same obfuscation technique is used within the Wineloader HTA sample analyzed by ARC Labs. In the sample, ARC Labs identified an array named <strong>_0x575da0</strong>, which contains an array of hexadecimal encoded string values. The variable <strong>_0x575da0</strong> is repeatedly called through a replace function named <strong>_0x12e9</strong>, which navigates through several complicated steps to eventually call an element within the array.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="936" height="368" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader5.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080311" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader5.png 936w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader5-300x118.png 300w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader5-768x302.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 936px) 100vw, 936px" /></figure></div>


<p>To reveal the string values leveraged within the HTA payload, defenders can simply copy the array and replace function to a new JavaScript value and pass the same data, then output the decoded data.</p>



<p>For example, the first function called within the Wineloader HTA is <strong>Majshkj</strong>, which is called with several obfuscated values.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="936" height="64" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader6.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080312" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader6.png 936w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader6-300x21.png 300w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader6-768x53.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 936px) 100vw, 936px" /></figure></div>


<p>Using the existing replace function (<strong>_0x12e9</strong>) and encoded array (<strong>_0x575da0</strong>) along with <strong>console.log</strong> reveals the encoded data as a string.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="936" height="430" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader7.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080313" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader7.png 936w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader7-300x138.png 300w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader7-768x353.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 936px) 100vw, 936px" /></figure></div>


<p>Repeating this process where the replace function is used will enable defenders to extract command line arguments, URLs, file names, and other threat intelligence that will enable them to assess their organizations for indicators of compromise.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Wineloader Execution</strong></h2>



<p>In the deobfuscated JavaScript, the HTA file performs pre-checks before continuing with the next stages of infection. To recreate the full infection process, ARC Labs modified the script to make it appear as though the remote host was alive so the infection would continue.</p>


<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="936" height="550" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader8.png" alt="" class="wp-image-10080314" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader8.png 936w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader8-300x176.png 300w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Wineloader8-768x451.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 936px) 100vw, 936px" /></figure></div>

<div class="wp-block-image">
<figure class="aligncenter size-full"><img loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="1272" height="679" src="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Screenshot-2024-06-03-at-3.49.00 PM.png" alt="WINELOADER EXECUTION " class="wp-image-10080319" srcset="https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Screenshot-2024-06-03-at-3.49.00 PM.png 1272w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Screenshot-2024-06-03-at-3.49.00 PM-300x160.png 300w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Screenshot-2024-06-03-at-3.49.00 PM-1024x547.png 1024w, https://www.binarydefense.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Screenshot-2024-06-03-at-3.49.00 PM-768x410.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1272px) 100vw, 1272px" /></figure></div>


<p>Recreation of the full infection chain also revealed the direct launching of code through <strong>mshta.exe</strong> without the need for an additional process. <strong>Mshta.exe</strong> is a legitimate Windows program that executes HTML files. This aids in direct defense evasion on the system by limiting the number of processes spawned on the compromised device in terms of script execution processes.</p>



<p>ARC Labs analysis revealed the final stages of the infection chain included downloading an additional file named <strong>text.txt</strong>, which was an encoded archive containing <strong>sqlwriter.exe</strong> and <strong>vcruntime140.dll</strong> where <strong>sqlwriter.exe</strong> is the legitimate Microsoft application and <strong>vcruntime140.dll</strong> is the Wineloader payload.</p>



<p>The malicious DLL is loaded automatically when <strong>sqlwriter.exe</strong> executes because of the way Microsoft Windows handles locating DLLs referenced by executables in their reference tables. If the full path of a DLL is not specified within the reference table, the executable will go through a predefined list of locations to search for the referenced DLL. In Microsoft Windows, the first location searched is the current working directory of the executable, so by placing the malicious DLL within the same folder as <strong>sqlwriter.exe</strong>, the malicious DLL is automatically located first and loaded by the executable. This technique is referred to as “sideloading”.</p>



<p>Once the DLL is sideloaded into <strong>sqlwriter.exe</strong>, Wineloader will attempt to establish persistence on the host by creating a scheduled task for <strong>sqlwriter.exe</strong> or by establishing registry persistence at the following key:</p>



<p><strong>HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\MS SQL Writer</strong></p>



<p>After persistence of Wineloader is established on the device, the backdoor will send specific beacon requests to the dedicated command-and-control server to notify persistence completion. At the time of analysis, the specified C2 server was offline, inhibiting any further analysis. However, as Wineloader is a first-stage backdoor, it is highly likely that a second-stage malicious payload would be transferred from the command-and-control server to the compromised device.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Detection Opportunities:</strong></h2>



<p>Information for executing threat hunts for evidence of Wineloader activity can be found within the ARC Labs Hunting Queries GitHub repository located here: <a href="https://github.com/BinaryDefense/ARC-Labs-Hunting-Queries" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">https://github.com/BinaryDefense/ARC-Labs-Hunting-Queries</a>. <br><br><strong>For more information about how Binary Defense can deliver <a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/services/managed-detection-and-response/">Managed Detection and Response</a> or <a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/services/threat-hunting/">Threat Hunting </a>services that can identify Wineloader activity, </strong><a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/contact-us/"><strong>contact us</strong></a><strong> to set up a follow on conversation.</strong></p>
    </div> <!-- @end .entry-content -->
    
</article> <!-- @end #post-10080306 -->
        
    </div>
            <div class="post-aside" data-position="left">

        </article>

    <div class="post-content">
        <div class="post-meta">
            <p class="post-badge">Blog</p>            <p class="publish-date">
                Sep. 19, 2024            </p>
        </div>
        <h3 class="post-title">Shining a Light in the Dark – How Binary Defense Uncovered an APT Lurking in Shadows of IT</h3>            </div>
                        <a href="https://www.binarydefense.com/resources/blog/shining-a-light-in-the-dark-how-binary-defense-uncovered-an-apt-lurking-in-shadows-of-it/" class="post-read-more">
                Read More        </a>
                <svg id="a" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 266.59 283.57"><defs><style>.e{fill:#d6dbe3;}</style></defs><g id="b"><g id="c"><path class="e" <footer id="footer">
    
    <div style="--bindef--footer-cta-badge-width: 50px; --bindef--footer-cta-trust-badge-width: 240px;" class="footer-cta">
